posts.name: Hailey
posts.cooked:
New versions of KLib’s Design Accelerator and a brand new Strategy Calculator are now available!

The Strategy Calculator allows you to calculate which tasks are worth a certain amount of points per second to allow easier and more accurate Strategic Design decisions

The Strategy Calculator allows you to calculate which tasks are worth a certain amount of points per second to allow easier and more accurate Strategic Design decisions

Also comes with a robot cycle calculator using hypothetical numbers!

Also comes with a robot cycle calculator using hypothetical numbers!

Design Accelerator now includes an Intake tab to better calculate surface feet per second of that intake that’s always bothersome to calculate

Design Accelerator now includes an Intake tab to better calculate surface feet per second of that intake that’s always bothersome to calculate

Comes with a free Indexer Calculator under the shooter tab to see if you are choking your shooter, or the other way around

Comes with a free Indexer Calculator under the shooter tab to see if you are choking your shooter, or the other way around

In other news, I might be starting a blog talking about my personal perspective and design choices/thoughts as I design an Everybot for this game. I’d love to know what are your guys’ thoughts on me doing this are! :))

KLib , V3.1.0 https://workbench.grabcad.com/workbench/projects/gc-RpR7Cho3qxjpj6y9KAs8wP2dz0krMqKR8V6s1cJmZ11#/space/gc6_kyHzFPwp8y2Yd-2Y-VBaIWPnmrVJ0IUKS2qhN4aona KLib Design Accelerator , V3.0.2 https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1_lq-DJtIxfeR5EDhH8MlSsLPXyn2Xl6eg9ZceDtz9OM/edit?usp=sharing KLib Strategy Calculator , V1.0.0 https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1BvstxD9i05EpcNt0L1NATyZ4H1yPpFmIqZfjGJtU9cA/edit?usp=sharing

posts.name: Hailey
posts.cooked:
Development for KLib 2024 is in full swing, if you have any suggestions or ideas, or even just bug reports, please let me know!

Currently the biggest focus has been the Design Accelerator, currently changes consist of…

Automatic part & mounting report for inputted Center Distances

Center Distances reformatted to only highlight currently used columns, alongside being slimmer and easier to look at and use

Custom transmissions can easily be added to Center Distances under a new tab called Data

Automatic Mechanical Efficiency ratings are calculated for you, just have to tell the Calculator what stages are what types of transmission (20 DP gear, 5mm HTD Belt, Chain (lubricated or unlubricated,) and so forth

Split the manifold/pcm/pc, air useage, and piston center distance calculators up into their respective sheets. Manifold/pcm/pc is now combined with electronics tracking

A new sheet for calculating combinations of planetary gearboxes for Versa, Ultra, and Maxplanetary series. Used for seeing which stages will break under the desired load

Drivetrain now comes with acceleration, force on impact at 25%, 50%, and 100% speed. Pulled math from the ILITE drivetrain calculator and implemented that into KLib. Also combined Swerve, Drivetrain 1 and 2 speeds all into one singular sheet

Reformated every sheet to be eaiser to read and use

And currently being worked on is…

I have the calculations done for when gears and belts will break under what loads, but have yet to find a single resource that can explain how the stress is distributed across a gearbox and what the relation there is. Currently attempting to 3D print a test rig for figure out that relationship and then implement that into the calculator so you’ll be able to see when your sprockets, pinions, pulleys, gears, and belts will fail

Similar to above, planning on creating a traction rig to explore what the coefficient of friction for various types of wheels and tread to get better and more accurate Drivetrain calculation/acceleration numbers

Moving on to the Parts Library

This has been put on hold for the better part of a year due to the shear number of products being released by everybody, not to mention GrabCAD shutting down, but it will still continue to be developed.

Every new product released since Houston of 2022 to 2024 from WCP and REV will be added, alongside some new spacer and Standoff Generators

A Google Drive will be created and act as the new home for the download of KLib

I think thats it from me, if you have any ideas, suggestions or input, please let me know! Thanks for reading

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Awesome stuff!

I’d be happy to help with the gearbox failures question!  There’s a few ways they go.  For our purposes, the 1 failure is tooth breakage.  You should have the formulas for tooth bending strength.  To apply those, you need to calculate the force at the tooth interface (pitch line) for each mesh and evaluate the large and small gear’s bending strength.  One or both teeth can fail.  For gearboxes with just one type of gear teeth the failure will occur at the highest torque point; normally the output gear and its pinion.

Tooth wear is also another failure point, but that will require some information on lubrication and probably some guesses on shaft support and mis-alignment.  Much less catastrophic!

You might also want to do a basic check on 1/2" hex shaft in 6061 and 7075; with high ratios you can twist it off.  About 46 ft-lbs for 7075 and 29 ft-lbs for 6061.  It really doesn’t matter if there is a hole in the middle or not; that area doesn’t make a significant contribution in torsion.

posts.name: Hailey
posts.cooked:
How do you know the distribution from the “input” stress in relation to the diameter of the gears, I imagine the pitch diameter would affect how much torque is being applied to the meshing tooth profile

I am able to use the Lewis factor to get a seemingly good estimate for # of pounds that a tooth can take before giving way under load using the tensile strength of the material but I am unsure how to calculate the actual load the tooth is receiving.

Also I am curious where you got the 46/29 ft-lbs for twisting hex, can I see those calculations? I am sure they’d come in handy in the future for something I am not expecting

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: KLib Design Accelerator is the bees knees.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked:
Sorry, distracted by work emergencies…

Gearbox calc:  Take the input torque (say 1 pound inch) and you gear in question.  Say its a 25 tooth 20 DP gear.  The pitch line diameter is 25 teeth/20 DP or 1.25".  The pitch line radius is half that or 0.625.  The force on the teeth is the torque divided by the pitch line radius; 1 pound inch/0.625" or 1.6 pounds.  The exact same force is applied to the mating gear’s teeth.

For normal gears the number of teeth in contact at any given time is in the range of 1.2 to 1.8.  Backlash will decrease this ratio, and it will never go below 1.  Our standard gears are 20DP, 14.5 degree pressure angle.  Honestly, 20 degrees would be a better choice, but that’s what we have…   I would be shocked if we got as high as 1.2!  I would do your tooth bending strength calculation based on ONE tooth carrying the load.

For torsional failure in shafts, you need the tensile strength in shear for the material.  If you don’t have the number, use half the yield strength.  6061 T6: 30 ksi.  7075: 48 ksi.  The polar moment of intertia of the shaft is what controls the failure strength.  Basically, the farther the metal is away from the centerline, the more valuable it is.  Metal on the centerline is useless for torsion, so the hole in the middle of our standard shafts has no significant effect on the torsional strength.  The clipped corners on some of our shafting will have some effect, but its going to be fairly small due to the small area.

For a round shaft the torsional yield is (max shear stress) * (pi/16) D^3.  So, for a 1/2" round shaft of 6061T6 Aluminum:  30,000psi * 0.196 (0.5)^3 or 735 inch pounds.

For a hex shaft the torsional yield is (max shear stress) * 0.123 D^3.  NOTE: D here is the point to point dimension!  For 1/2" hex that’s 0.577".  So, for a 1/2" across the flats hex shaft of 6061T6 Aluminum:  30,000psi * 0.123 (0.577)^3 or 709 inch pounds.  Looks like I missed a factor of 2 in my number above!  A 1/8" hole in the shaft only costs you 11 inch pounds of torsional strength.

So:  6061 hex about 59 foot pounds and 94 foot pounds for 7075.  This is why trying to run an arm on 1/2" hex shaft ends badly…  Plus, of course, you can also round out the hole in the mating parts! Keep in mind that bending load and shear load can SIGNIFICANTLY reduce this!

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked:
For gear tooth bending, you want to look at Lewis Bending Stress equations. This slideshow that I found from a quick google search seems to cover it pretty well.

In general though, it’s pretty hard to get standard FRC gears to fail under quasi-static load. You need like four stages of gears to get into the danger zone. What’s a lot more likely to cause problems is shock-loading, where the loads can get an order of magnitude or two higher. That’s a common problem with drivetrains or arms that don’t have a chain/belt stage to take up the shock. Shock loads are much harder to predict and quantify though, so you probably won’t be able to model them in a calculator.

posts.name: Hailey
posts.cooked:
Ohh okay. I will explore these formulas and ?might? even test them at 1902’s space or my work at some point just to verify/tweak some numbers around. Thank you for the very insightful response and I appreciate you taking the time to answer and reply

Also you didnt have to apologize for having a work emergency, I hope everything is well!!

posts.name: Hailey
posts.cooked: I found that the very last stage is within 0.01% of taking perfectly half of the force of an impact load, and then the rest is distributed mostly via ratio, and a bit with contact. So as a rough estimate that’s what I programmed my gearbox force-load calculator with in the newest version

posts.name: Hailey
posts.cooked:
Design Accelerator V5.5

Intro

Welcome!
Welcome to the CAD resource sheet! Here you will find anything you will require for CAD. This includes links, tolerances, calculators, resources, as well as other things that can help you CAD anything you require
Cell Color...

Reformatted Linear, Rotary, Intake, and Shooter to closer resemble each other.

Current draw has been split into stator and supply and in the same cell so a future match-length power calculator can be created if desired.

Linear now uses trapezoidal exponential acceleration to get more accurate real world travel times.

Drive has incorporated the Ilite acceleration engine alongside a few tweaks to give a ft-lb output for Stress Analyzing parts in CAD programs, and allows for 1 or 2 - speed drivetrains.

Swerve turning has been separated into its own sheet to not overload the new Drive sheet with parameters.

Acceleration modifies the variables in the drive sheet, again to split up the many variables

COTS Swerve Lookup has been added to look at stock swerve speeds and data without having to lookup or recalculate anything

Center Distances got an overhaul, any unused calculation cell turns into a muddy gray to be easier on the eyes and reprogrammed with error detection

Various now includes a transmission stack-up center distance subtract

A brand new never-before seen Gearbox Builder is now part of the library, tells you when your gears/sprockets/belts/chains will break upon impact or running at - 100% from the motor

The planetary sheet does the same thing but for the UP/MP/VP systems

Elec. Info got updated with more electronics

Elec. tracking was overhauled to better ease the user interface

Pneu. Tracking now offers a match-long PSI graph that will turn on and off the compressor while using pistons throughout the match to see if you have enough air - and where your lowest PSI is so you can use 60/lowest PSI as your safety factor for designing with pistons

The Motors sheet now has the Kraken X60/NEO Vortex as well as the FOC for the Kraken X60 and Falcon 500

Data Input is where the user can now input data that the rest of the calculator will update with

Vex has been removed from Vendors due to the on-going issues with the company

Added a contact sheet

I’m sure there’s more I’m forgetting, just trying to get this out before the 2024 Season!

P.S. a big thank you to the people on Discord and the feedback here on Delphi that has lead to so many wonderful QoL changes, looking forwards to version 6! <3
